body:
@ianlancetaylor 

>  Every change to the language has a cost: it's an additional thing that users of the language need to learn and understand

I understand, and I am fine with your decision not to include this, however for me it felt as if the extra thing I needed to remember (the "exception") is that short declaration doesn't work with case statements instead of it being consistent through out the language.

>  One way to measure the benefit is to look through a body of Go code and see how often this could be used.

I don't have millions of lines I could run a script on to check this. Word on the street is that google has tools that can do this type of analysis on their existing bodies of code. Do you think you could run such an analysis and share the data? Perhaps I've misunderstood what is possible.

> That said, I don't understand how your initial example could work anyhow.

Sorry about that, I guess I didn't explain clearly. Put another way, the idea is to have a readable case statement which can match many different error conditions, including some that require short declaration to see if the err is of the correct type.

Thanks again for your time and keep up the great work! (not sarcasm)

Cheers,
James
